required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Sativex Versus Placebo When Added to Existing Treatment for Central Neuropathic Pain in MS
clinical_study.official_title: A Double Blind, Randomised, Placebo Controlled, Parallel Group Study of Sativex When Added to the Existing Treatment Regimen, in the Relief of Central Neuropathic Pain in Subjects With Multiple Sclerosis

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to find out if cannabis-based medicine compared to a dummy medicine (placebo that contains no active ingredient) can help the central neuropathic pain patients experience as a result of multiple sclerosis. This type of pain "central neuropathic pain" is described as shooting, stabbing, burning or searing like sensation, which is often worse at night.

detailed_description.textblock: GW has shown in phase II and III studies that Sativex has analgesic properties that are effective in relieving neuropathic pain. These studies suggested that Sativex is well tolerated and may also improve sleep and quality of life. GW is conducting this study to further demonstrate these effects.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in Mean Pain Due to MS NRS Score
primary_outcome.time_frame: 14 weeks: Baseline - End of Treatment (last 7 days of treatment)
primary_outcome.description: The pain NRS was completed at the same time each day, i.e. bedtime in the evening. The patient was asked "on a scale of '0 to 10', please indicate the number that best describes your pain in the last 24 hours" where 0 = no pain and 10 = pain as bad as you can imagine. No pain relates to the time prior to the onset of pain due to multiple sclerosis. A negative value indicates an improvement in pain score from baseline.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of Patients With at Least 30% Improvement in Numerical Rating Scale (NRS) Pain Score From Baseline
primary_outcome.time_frame: 14 weeks: Baseline - end of treatment (last 7 days)
primary_outcome.description: A positive 30% pain response is defined as a reduction of at least 30% in the mean NRS pain score from baseline to week 14 (last 7 days). The patient was asked "on a scale of '0 to 10', please indicate the number that best describes your pain in the last 24 hours" where 0 = no pain and 10 = pain as bad as you can imagine. No pain relates to the time prior to the onset of pain due to multiple sclerosis. The pain NRS was completed at the same time each day, i.e. bedtime in the evening.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Pain From Baseline to End of the Treatment Using the NPS (Neuropathic Pain Scale)
secondary_outcome.description: The NPS score is 0-100 sum of 10 individual pain scores (0-10 NRS, 0= no pain to 10 = most pain imaginable). A negative change from baseline indicates an improvement in pain.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline to End of Treatment in Break-through Analgesia Usage
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 14 weeks: baseline - end of treatment (last 7 days)
secondary_outcome.description: Use of break through medication was recorded daily during the 14 weeks of the study as the number of paracetamol tablets taken. The change in mean daily quantities of tablets used was calculated from baseline to the last seven days of treatment.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline to End of Treatment in BPI (Brief Pain Inventory) Short Form
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 14 weeks: Baseline to end of treatment (last 7 days of treatment)
secondary_outcome.description: The BPI-SF is a 14-item questionnaire that asks patients to rate pain over the prior week and the degree to which it interferes with activities on a 0 to 10 scale, where 0=no pain and 10=pain as bad as you can imagine. Severity is measured as worst pain, least pain, average pain, and pain right now. The severity composite score was calculated as the arithmetic mean of the four severity items(range 0-10). The minimum value is zero and maximum is 10. A higher score represents a poor outcome.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Subject Global Impression of Change (SGIC)
secondary_outcome.description: A 7-point Likert-type scale was used, with the question: 'Please assess the status of your pain due to multiple sclerosis since entry into the study using the scale below' with the markers "very much improved, much improved, slightly improved, no change, slightly worse, much worse or very much worse". At baseline subjects wrote a brief description of their pain caused by multiple sclerosis which was used at Week 14 to aid their memory regarding their symptoms at study start. For each of above markers the number of participants were reported.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: 14 weeks; Baseline to end of treatment (last 7 days)
secondary_outcome.description: The sleep disruption NRS was completed at the same time each day, i.e. bedtime in the evening. The patient was asked "on a scale of '0 to 10', please indicate how your pain disrupted your sleep last night?" where 0 = did not disrupt sleep and 10 = completely disrupted (unable to sleep at all). A negative value indicates an improvement in sleep disruption score from baseline.

intervention.description: Containing D9 tetrahydrocannabinol (THC), 27 mg/ml: cannabidiol (CBD), 25 mg/ml, as extracts of Cannabis sativa L. Delivered in 100 µl actuations by a pump action oromucosal spray. Maximum dose within any 24-hour interval 12 sprays (THC 32.5 mg: CBD 30 mg.
Containing colourants and excipients. Delivered in 100 µl actuations by a pump action oromucosal spray. Maximum dose within any 24-hour interval 12 sprays.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Any disease sub-type of MS of at least two years duration
- Central neuropathic pain (CNP) of at least three months and expected to remain stable for the study duration
- Moderate CNP defined by NRS pain score at baseline sum to at least 24
- Subject established on or previously tried and failed analgesic therapy for CNP
- If receiving disease modifying medications, stable dose for 3 months and maintained for study duration
Exclusion Criteria:
- Subjects whose identified pain is likely to be nociceptive, musculoskeletal (including spasms) peripheral neuropathic or psychogenic in origin, or due to trigeminal neuralgia.
- Other non central neuropathic pain of a severity which is likely to interfere with the patients assessment of CNP
- medical history suggests subject is likely to relapse/remit during course of study
- history of schizophrenia (including family history), other psychotic illness, severe personality disorder or other significant psychiatric disorder other than depression associated with MS
- known or suspected history of alcohol abuse, epilepsy or recurrent seizures or hypersensitivity to cannabinoids
- travel outside of the country of residence planned during the study
- significant cardiac, renal or hepatic impairment
- subjects with current recreational cannabis, medicinal cannabis or synthetic cannabinoid based medications within 3 months prior to study entry and unwilling to abstain for the duration of the study

facility.name: Multiple Sclerosis Program, Foothills Hospital SSB
London Health Sciences Centre / University Hospital

results_reference.citation: Langford RM, Mares J, Novotna A, Vachova M, Novakova I, Notcutt W, Ratcliffe S. A double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled, parallel-group study of THC/CBD oromucosal spray in combination with the existing treatment regimen, in the relief of central neuropathic pain in patients with multiple sclerosis. J Neurol. 2013 Apr;260(4):984-97. doi: 10.1007/s00415-012-6739-4. Epub 2012 Nov 21.

group.title: Sativex
group.description: Range of 8 -12 sprays per day. Each actuation of oromucosal spray delivers 2.7 mg delta-9-tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) and 2.5 mg cannabidiol (CBD). Thus maximum daily dose is 32.4 mg THC and 30 mg CBD.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Range of 8-12 sprays per day of placebo spray.

group.title: Sativex
group.description: Range of 8 -12 sprays per day. Each actuation of oromucosal spray delivers 2.7 mg delta-9-tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) and 2.5 mg cannabidiol (CBD). Thus maximum daily dose is 32.4 mg THC and 30 mg CBD.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Range of 8-12 sprays per day of placebo spray.

group.title: Total
group.description: Total of all reporting groups

measure.title: Baseline Pain Numerical Rating Scale (NRS) score
measure.description: Pain severity NRS was completed daily by answering the following question: 'On a scale of '0 to 10' please indicate the average level of your nerve pain at your chosen site over the last day', with the anchors: 0='no pain' and 10= 'worst possible pain'.

outcome.title: Change in Mean Pain Due to MS NRS Score
outcome.description: The pain NRS was completed at the same time each day, i.e. bedtime in the evening. The patient was asked "on a scale of '0 to 10', please indicate the number that best describes your pain in the last 24 hours" where 0 = no pain and 10 = pain as bad as you can imagine. No pain relates to the time prior to the onset of pain due to multiple sclerosis. A negative value indicates an improvement in pain score from baseline.
outcome.time_frame: 14 weeks: Baseline - End of Treatment (last 7 days of treatment)
outcome.population: Change in mean daily NRS score

group.title: Sativex
group.description: Range of 8 -12 sprays per day. Each actuation of oromucosal spray delivers 2.7 mg delta-9-tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) and 2.5 mg cannabidiol (CBD). Thus maximum daily dose is 32.4 mg THC and 30 mg CBD.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Range of 8-12 sprays of placebo per day

measure.title: Change in Mean Pain Due to MS NRS Score
measure.description: The pain NRS was completed at the same time each day, i.e. bedtime in the evening. The patient was asked "on a scale of '0 to 10', please indicate the number that best describes your pain in the last 24 hours" where 0 = no pain and 10 = pain as bad as you can imagine. No pain relates to the time prior to the onset of pain due to multiple sclerosis. A negative value indicates an improvement in pain score from baseline.
measure.population: Change in mean daily NRS score

analysis.groups_desc: The change in pain NRS score from baseline to the end of study was analyzed using analysis of covariance (ANCOVA) with the baseline value as a covariate and centre group and treatment as factors.

outcome.title: Number of Patients With at Least 30% Improvement in Numerical Rating Scale (NRS) Pain Score From Baseline
outcome.description: A positive 30% pain response is defined as a reduction of at least 30% in the mean NRS pain score from baseline to week 14 (last 7 days). The patient was asked "on a scale of '0 to 10', please indicate the number that best describes your pain in the last 24 hours" where 0 = no pain and 10 = pain as bad as you can imagine. No pain relates to the time prior to the onset of pain due to multiple sclerosis. The pain NRS was completed at the same time each day, i.e. bedtime in the evening.
outcome.time_frame: 14 weeks: Baseline - end of treatment (last 7 days)

group.title: Sativex
group.description: Range of 8 -12 sprays per day. Each actuation of oromucosal spray delivers 2.7 mg delta-9-tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) and 2.5 mg cannabidiol (CBD). Thus maximum daily dose is 32.4 mg THC and 30 mg CBD.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Range of 8-12 sprays of placebo per day

measure.title: Number of Patients With at Least 30% Improvement in Numerical Rating Scale (NRS) Pain Score From Baseline
measure.description: A positive 30% pain response is defined as a reduction of at least 30% in the mean NRS pain score from baseline to week 14 (last 7 days). The patient was asked "on a scale of '0 to 10', please indicate the number that best describes your pain in the last 24 hours" where 0 = no pain and 10 = pain as bad as you can imagine. No pain relates to the time prior to the onset of pain due to multiple sclerosis. The pain NRS was completed at the same time each day, i.e. bedtime in the evening.

analysis.groups_desc: The proportions of responders were compared between the treatment groups using logistic regression with region and treatment groups as factors. The null hypothesis was that there was no difference between each Sativex and placebo.

outcome.title: Change in Pain From Baseline to End of the Treatment Using the NPS (Neuropathic Pain Scale)
outcome.description: The NPS score is 0-100 sum of 10 individual pain scores (0-10 NRS, 0= no pain to 10 = most pain imaginable). A negative change from baseline indicates an improvement in pain.

group.title: Sativex
group.description: Range of 8 -12 sprays per day. Each actuation of oromucosal spray delivers 2.7 mg delta-9-tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) and 2.5 mg cannabidiol (CBD). Thus maximum daily dose is 32.4 mg THC and 30 mg CBD.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Range of 8-12 sprays of placebo per day

measure.title: Change in Pain From Baseline to End of the Treatment Using the NPS (Neuropathic Pain Scale)
measure.description: The NPS score is 0-100 sum of 10 individual pain scores (0-10 NRS, 0= no pain to 10 = most pain imaginable). A negative change from baseline indicates an improvement in pain.

analysis.groups_desc: The change in NPS score from baseline to the end of study was analyzed using analysis of covariance (ANCOVA) with the baseline value as a covariate and centre group and treatment as factors.
analysis.estimate_desc: A negative difference in estimated treatment effect indicates an improvement in pain in favour of Sativex.

outcome.title: Change From Baseline to End of Treatment in Break-through Analgesia Usage
outcome.description: Use of break through medication was recorded daily during the 14 weeks of the study as the number of paracetamol tablets taken. The change in mean daily quantities of tablets used was calculated from baseline to the last seven days of treatment.
outcome.time_frame: 14 weeks: baseline - end of treatment (last 7 days)

group.title: Sativex
group.description: Range of 8 -12 sprays per day. Each actuation of oromucosal spray delivers 2.7 mg delta-9-tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) and 2.5 mg cannabidiol (CBD). Thus maximum daily dose is 32.4 mg THC and 30 mg CBD.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Range of 8-12 sprays of placebo per day

measure.title: Change From Baseline to End of Treatment in Break-through Analgesia Usage
measure.description: Use of break through medication was recorded daily during the 14 weeks of the study as the number of paracetamol tablets taken. The change in mean daily quantities of tablets used was calculated from baseline to the last seven days of treatment.

analysis.groups_desc: The change in average number of tablets taken daily from baseline to the end of study was analyzed using analysis of covariance (ANCOVA) with the baseline value as a covariate and centre group and treatment as factors.
analysis.estimate_desc: A negative difference in estimated treatment difference indicates a reduction in breakthrough analgesic medication in favour of Sativex.

outcome.title: Change From Baseline to End of Treatment in BPI (Brief Pain Inventory) Short Form
outcome.description: The BPI-SF is a 14-item questionnaire that asks patients to rate pain over the prior week and the degree to which it interferes with activities on a 0 to 10 scale, where 0=no pain and 10=pain as bad as you can imagine. Severity is measured as worst pain, least pain, average pain, and pain right now. The severity composite score was calculated as the arithmetic mean of the four severity items(range 0-10). The minimum value is zero and maximum is 10. A higher score represents a poor outcome.
outcome.time_frame: 14 weeks: Baseline to end of treatment (last 7 days of treatment)
outcome.population: All subjects who completed the BPI-short form were included in the analysis. Four subjects from the sativex group and three subjects from the placebo group did not complete the form.

group.title: Sativex
group.description: Range of 8 -12 sprays per day. Each actuation of oromucosal spray delivers 2.7 mg delta-9-tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) and 2.5 mg cannabidiol (CBD). Thus maximum daily dose is 32.4 mg THC and 30 mg CBD.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Range of 8-12 sprays of placebo per day

measure.title: Change From Baseline to End of Treatment in BPI (Brief Pain Inventory) Short Form
measure.description: The BPI-SF is a 14-item questionnaire that asks patients to rate pain over the prior week and the degree to which it interferes with activities on a 0 to 10 scale, where 0=no pain and 10=pain as bad as you can imagine. Severity is measured as worst pain, least pain, average pain, and pain right now. The severity composite score was calculated as the arithmetic mean of the four severity items(range 0-10). The minimum value is zero and maximum is 10. A higher score represents a poor outcome.
measure.population: All subjects who completed the BPI-short form were included in the analysis. Four subjects from the sativex group and three subjects from the placebo group did not complete the form.

analysis.estimate_desc: A negative difference in estimated means indicates an improvement in pain in favour of Sativex.

outcome.title: Change in Subject Global Impression of Change (SGIC)
outcome.description: A 7-point Likert-type scale was used, with the question: ‘Please assess the status of your pain due to multiple sclerosis since entry into the study using the scale below’ with the markers “very much improved, much improved, slightly improved, no change, slightly worse, much worse or very much worse”. At baseline subjects wrote a brief description of their pain caused by multiple sclerosis which was used at Week 14 to aid their memory regarding their symptoms at study start. For each of above markers the number of participants were reported.
outcome.population: All subjects who completed the question were included in the analysis. Two subjects from the Sativex group and six subjects from the placebo group did not complete the question.

group.title: Sativex
group.description: Range of 8 -12 sprays per day. Each actuation of oromucosal spray delivers 2.7 mg delta-9-tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) and 2.5 mg cannabidiol (CBD). Thus maximum daily dose is 32.4 mg THC and 30 mg CBD.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Range of 8-12 sprays of placebo per day

measure.title: Change in Subject Global Impression of Change (SGIC)
measure.description: A 7-point Likert-type scale was used, with the question: ‘Please assess the status of your pain due to multiple sclerosis since entry into the study using the scale below’ with the markers “very much improved, much improved, slightly improved, no change, slightly worse, much worse or very much worse”. At baseline subjects wrote a brief description of their pain caused by multiple sclerosis which was used at Week 14 to aid their memory regarding their symptoms at study start. For each of above markers the number of participants were reported.
measure.population: All subjects who completed the question were included in the analysis. Two subjects from the Sativex group and six subjects from the placebo group did not complete the question.

analysis.estimate_desc: An odds ratio of greater than 1 indicates and improvement in favour of Sativex.

outcome.title: Change in Sleep Disruption NRS
outcome.description: The sleep disruption NRS was completed at the same time each day, i.e. bedtime in the evening. The patient was asked "on a scale of '0 to 10', please indicate how your pain disrupted your sleep last night?" where 0 = did not disrupt sleep and 10 = completely disrupted (unable to sleep at all). A negative value indicates an improvement in sleep disruption score from baseline.
outcome.time_frame: 14 weeks; Baseline to end of treatment (last 7 days)

group.title: Sativex
group.description: Range of 8 -12 sprays per day. Each actuation of oromucosal spray delivers 2.7 mg delta-9-tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) and 2.5 mg cannabidiol (CBD). Thus maximum daily dose is 32.4 mg THC and 30 mg CBD.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Range of 8-12 sprays of placebo per day

measure.title: Change in Sleep Disruption NRS
measure.description: The sleep disruption NRS was completed at the same time each day, i.e. bedtime in the evening. The patient was asked "on a scale of '0 to 10', please indicate how your pain disrupted your sleep last night?" where 0 = did not disrupt sleep and 10 = completely disrupted (unable to sleep at all). A negative value indicates an improvement in sleep disruption score from baseline.

analysis.estimate_desc: A negative difference in estimated treatment difference indicates an improvement in sleep quality in favour of Sativex.

reported_events.time_frame: All adverse events occurring from time of consent to post study follow up i.e. 15 weeks were collected. All deaths and serious adverse events occurring within 28 days of the final dose of study medications were also collected/
reported_events.desc: All adverse events occurring during the study were reported on the running logs at the back of the study case report form.

group.title: Sativex
group.description: Range of 8 -12 sprays per day. Each actuation of oromucosal spray delivers 2.7 mg delta-9-tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) and 2.5 mg cannabidiol (CBD). Thus maximum daily dose is 32.4 mg THC and 30 mg CBD.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Range of 8-12 sprays of placebo per day

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: GW will coordinate the dissemination of data from this study and may solicit input and assistance from the principal investigator. All publications for example, manuscripts, abstracts, oral/slide presentations or book chapters based on this study, must be submitted to GW for corporate review before release.
